pyinterpolate.kriging.models.block package#

Submodules#

pyinterpolate.kriging.models.block.area_to_area_poisson_kriging module#

Area-to-area Poisson Kriging function.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

area_to_area_pk(semivariogram_model: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], unknown_block: ndarray, unknown_block_point_support: ndarray, number_of_neighbors: int, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True)[source]#

Function predicts areal value in a unknown location based on the area-to-area Poisson Kriging

Parameters:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì Regularized variogram.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

    Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

    • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì

    • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

    • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

    • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

    • PointSupport

  • unknown_block (numpy array) ‚Äì [index, centroid.x, centroid.y]

  • unknown_block_point_support (numpy array) ‚Äì Points within block [[x, y, point support value]]

  • number_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì The minimum number of neighbours that potentially affect block.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

Returns:

results ‚Äì [unknown block index, prediction, error]

Return type:

List

:raises ValueError : Prediction or prediction error are negative.:

pyinterpolate.kriging.models.block.area_to_point_poisson_kriging module#

Area-to-point Poisson Kriging function.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

area_to_point_pk(semivariogram_model: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], unknown_block: ndarray, unknown_block_point_support: ndarray, number_of_neighbors: int, max_range=None, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True, err_to_nan=True)[source]#

Function predicts areal value in a unknown location based on the area-to-area Poisson Kriging

Parameters:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì Regularized variogram.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

    Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

    • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì

    • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

    • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

    • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

    • PointSupport

  • unknown_block (numpy array) ‚Äì [index, centroid.x, centroid.y]

  • unknown_block_point_support (numpy array) ‚Äì Points within block [[x, y, point support value]]

  • number_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì The minimum number of neighbours that potentially affect block.

  • max_range (float) ‚Äì The maximum distance to search for a neighbors, if None given then algorithm uses the theoretical variogram range.

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

  • err_to_nan (bool, default=True) ‚Äì ValueError to NaN.

Returns:

results ‚Äì [(unknown point coordinates), prediction, error]

Return type:

List

:raises ValueError : Prediction or prediction error are negative.:

pyinterpolate.kriging.models.block.centroid_based_poisson_kriging module#

Centroid-based Poisson Kriging function.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

centroid_poisson_kriging(semivariogram_model: TheoreticalVariogram, blocks: Union[Blocks, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, ndarray], point_support: Union[Dict, ndarray, GeoDataFrame, DataFrame, PointSupport], unknown_block: ndarray, unknown_block_point_support: ndarray, number_of_neighbors: int, is_weighted_by_point_support=True, raise_when_negative_prediction=True, raise_when_negative_error=True) → List[source]#

Function performs centroid-based Poisson Kriging of blocks (areal) data.

Parameters:

  • semivariogram_model (TheoreticalVariogram) ‚Äì Fitted variogram.

  • blocks (Union[Blocks, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Blocks with aggregated data. * Blocks: Blocks() class object. * GeoDataFrame and DataFrame must have columns: centroid.x, centroid.y, ds, index.

    Geometry column with polygons is not used and optional.

    • numpy array: [[block index, centroid x, centroid y, value]].

  • point_support (Union[Dict, np.ndarray, gpd.GeoDataFrame, pd.DataFrame, PointSupport]) ‚Äì

    • Dict: {block id: [[point x, point y, value]]}

    • numpy array: [[block id, x, y, value]]

    • DataFrame and GeoDataFrame: columns={x, y, ds, index}

    • PointSupport

  • unknown_block (numpy array) ‚Äì [index, centroid.x, centroid.y]

  • unknown_block_point_support (numpy array) ‚Äì Points within block [[x, y, point support value]]

  • number_of_neighbors (int) ‚Äì The minimum number of neighbours that potentially affect block.

  • is_weighted_by_point_support (bool, default = True) ‚Äì Are distances between blocks weighted by point support?

  • raise_when_negative_prediction (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction is negative.

  • raise_when_negative_error (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Raise error when prediction error is negative.

Returns:

results ‚Äì [unknown block index, prediction, error]

Return type:

List

:raises ValueError : Prediction or prediction error are negative.:

pyinterpolate.kriging.models.block.weight module#

Array weighting classes and functions designed to solve kriging system for block Poisson Kriging models.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moli≈Ñski | @SimonMolinsky

class WeightedBlock2BlockSemivariance(semivariance_model)[source]#

Bases: object

Class calculates the average weighted block-to-block semivariance.

semivariance_modelTheoreticalVariogram

Fitted variogram model.

semivariance_modelTheoreticalVariogram

See semivariance_model parameter.

calculate_average_semivariance(datarows: Dict)

Function calculates the average semivariance from a given set of points and distances between them.

Weighted semivariance is calculated as:

$$gamma_{v_{i}, v_{j}}

=

rac{1}{sum_{s}^{P_{i}} sum_{s‚Äô}^{P_{j}} w_{ss‚Äô}} *

sum_{s}^{P_{i}} sum_{s‚Äô}^{P_{j}} w_{ss‚Äô} * gamma(u_{s}, u_{s‚Äô})$$

where: * $w_{ss‚Äô}$ - product of point-support weights from block a and block b. * $gamma(u_{s}, u_{s‚Äô})$ - semivariance between point-supports of block a and block b.

avg_semivar = WeightedBlock2BlockSemivariance(variogram_model) semivars = avg_semivar.calculate_average_semivariance(blocks_data) print(semivars) >>> {‚Äòblock x‚Äô: 200, ‚Äòblock y‚Äô: 300}

calculate_average_semivariance(data_points: Dict) → Dict[source]#

Function calculates the average semivariance.

Parameters:

data_points (Dict) ‚Äì {known block id: [(unknown x, unknown y), [unknown val, known val, distance between points]]}

Returns:

weighted_semivariances ‚Äì {area_id: weighted semivariance}

Return type:

Dict

class WeightedBlock2PointSemivariance(semivariance_model: TheoreticalVariogram)[source]#

Bases: object

Class calculates the average weighted block-to-point semivariance.

semivariance_modelTheoreticalVariogram

Fitted variogram model.

semivariance_modelTheoreticalVariogram

See semivariance_model parameter.

calculate_average_semivariance(datarows: Dict)

Function calculates the average semivariance from a given set of points and distances between them.

Weighted semivariance is calculated as:

$$gamma_{v_{i}, u_{s}}

=

rac{1}{sum_{s}^{P_{i}} sum_{s‚Äô}^{P_{j}} w_{ss‚Äô}} *

sum_{s}^{P_{i}} sum_{s‚Äô}^{P_{j}} w_{ss‚Äô} * gamma(u_{s}, u_{s‚Äô})$$

where:

  • $w_{ss‚Äô}$ - product of point-support weights from block a and block b.

  • $gamma(u_{s}, u_{s‚Äô})$ - semivariance between point-supports of block a and block b.

  • $P_{j}=1$ - only one semivariance value between a single point and all other points at a time.

avg_semivar = WeightedBlock2PointSemivariance(variogram_model) semivars = avg_semivar.calculate_average_semivariance(blocks_data) print(semivars) >>> ([[100, 200], [300, 200], [200, 100]])

calculate_average_semivariance(data_points: Dict) → ndarray[source]#

Function calculates average semivariance a single point from block Pj and all points from block Pi.

Parameters:

data_points (Dict) ‚Äì

{
known block id:

[(unknown x, unknown y), array(unknown val, known val, distance between points)]

} or {

block Pi id:
[

(block Pj point support point x_n, block Pj point support point y_n), array(

[value of unknown block (Pj) point-support point n, value of known block (Pi) point-support point i, distance between (x_n, y_n) and (x_i, y_i)], [value of unknown block (Pj) point-support point n, value of known block (Pi) point-support point i+1, distance between (x_n, y_n) and (x_i+1, y_i+1)], [‚Ä¶] )

]

}

Returns:

point_to_block_semivariances ‚Äì Predicted and weighted semivariances for each unknown block point support against known blocks. array(

[unknown point 1 (n) semivariance against point support from block 1, unknown point 2 (n+1) semivariance against point support from block 1, ‚Ä¶], [unknown point 1 (n) semivariance against point support from block 2, unknown point 2 (n+1) semivariance against point support from block 2, ‚Ä¶],

)

Return type:

numpy array

add_ones(array: ndarray) → ndarray[source]#

Function adds rows of ones to a given array.

Parameters:

array (numpy array) ‚Äì Array of size MxN (M rows, N cols)

Returns:

list_with_ones ‚Äì Array of size M+1xN (M+1 rows, N cols) where the last row are N ones.

Return type:

numpy array

weights_array(predicted_semivariances_shape, block_vals, point_support_vals) → array[source]#

Function calculates additional diagonal weights for the matrix of predicted semivariances.

Parameters:

  • predicted_semivariances_shape (Tuple) ‚Äì The size of semivariances array (nrows x ncols).

  • block_vals (numpy array) ‚Äì Array with values to calculate diagonal weight.

  • point_support_vals (numpy array) ‚Äì Array with values to calculate diagonal weight.

Returns:

The mask with zeros and diagonal weight of size (nrows x ncols).

Return type:

numpy array
